importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the start of demolition work on the East Wing of the White House to construct Trump's ballroom.
When President Trump initially announced the ballroom project, stating it would not interfere with the main White House structure and that the space would be near but not touching it.

When site preparation work, including clearing trees on the south grounds, began, and when the National Capital Planning Commission held a meeting where Will Scharf made a statement about jurisdiction over construction.
The projected completion date of the ballroom, before President Trump's term ends in January 2029.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which construction and demolition are underway, with the project expected to be completed before the end of Trump's presidential term.

keyTakeAways: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing to build a $250 million ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission.
President Trump claims the ballroom will not interfere with the main White House structure and will accommodate up to 999 people, increasing from the original 650-seat capacity.
The ballroom is described as the largest structural change to the Executive Mansion since the 1948 Truman Balcony addition.
Construction began on October 20, 2025, with work visible in dramatic photos showing the East Wing façade being torn down.
Trump claims the project is privately funded by 'Patriots, Great American Companies,' and himself, with no cost to taxpayers.
Carrier Global Corp. has donated an energy-efficient HVAC system for the ballroom, confirming their involvement.
The East Wing, built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, will have offices temporarily relocated during construction, though no offices will be permanently torn down.
The National Capital Planning Commission lacks jurisdiction over demolition and site preparation, according to White House staff secretary Will Scharf.
The White House has not submitted plans for formal review or approval, and the commission's offices are closed due to a government shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing in October 2025 to construct a $250 million ballroom for President Trump, despite not obtaining approval from the National Capital Planning Commission. Trump claims the project will not interfere with the main White House and will be privately funded, with no cost to taxpayers. The ballroom, expected to seat up to 999 people, is the largest structural change to the Executive Mansion since the 1948 Truman Balcony addition. The demolition has raised concerns over the displacement of offices, including those of the First Lady, and the lack of formal review. Carrier Global Corp. has donated an energy-efficient HVAC system for the new space. Construction is ongoing, with the project scheduled for completion before the end of Trump’s term in January 2029.
title: The White House starts demolishing part of the East Wing to build Trump's ballroom
